awd_titl_txt: A detector upgrade for OSIRIS: Doubling the sensitivity of the near-IR diffraction limited integral field spectrograph
awd_abstract_narration:
An exciting benefit of the semiconductor revolution that has had tremendous impact on astronomy at optical and infrared wavelengths has been the development of ever more sensitive array detectors.  These arrays are delivering hitherto-unimagined improvements in observing efficiency and enabling new and exciting science projects.  This project plans to carry out an upgrade to the array detector in the OSIRIS instrument deployed on the 10 meter Keck telescope on top of Mauna Kea.  The current science detector, called a Hawaii-2 (H2), will be replaced with a Hawaii-2RG (H2RG), which has a number of technical features that significantly enhance its performance.

The OSIRIS instrument is an integral-field spectrograph (IFS) fed by adaptive optics (AO); there are only a few such combinations in operation worldwide at the moment.  The non-common-path error is low, less than any other IFS, preserving the diffraction-limited point-spread-function delivered by the Keck AO system.  This has been a very productive combination scientifically.  The older array detector may be at some risk for failure simply due to its age; the newer array will offer higher sensitivity (twice as high at many wavelengths) and reduced detector artifacts.  It will have improved multiplexer performance that will greatly reduce channel-to-channel crosstalk and eliminate a reset anomaly that degrades some of the readouts in a commonly-used mode of observing.

The Keck telescopes have had a major impact on astronomy education, as evidenced by the 240 PhD theses (now averaging 20/year) produced as of early 2012 using Keck data.  Many leaders in U.S. astronomy are included in this number.  The WMKO (Keck Observatory) provides many graduate students and post-doctoral fellows direct access to state-of-the-art instrumentation, including adaptive optics.  The OSIRIS upgrade project in particular will involve a graduate student at UCLA.  

Funding for this project is being provided by NSF's Division of Astronomical Sciences through its Advanced Technologies and Instrumentation program.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF funded project help revitalize the OH- Suppressing Infra-Red Imaging Spectrograph (OSIRIS) by upgrading the detector hardware and readout system, improving the image quality by adding a focus stage mechanism, improving the instrument sensitivity, and updating the data reduction pipeline (DRP) for both real-time and post observing analysis. This project achieved all of the intended goals, and OSIRIS is now back on-sky, is regularly scheduled throughout the semester, and is in high demand. OSIRIS is now better equipped to study the galactic center, probe galaxy evolution, and resolve the morphologies of classic nova for example. 

Fed by the adaptive optics (AO) Keck I system, OSIRIS is an instrument with few competitors in the world. OSIRIS and AO regularly achieve diffraction-limited point-spread-function imaging and has been a very productive instrument scientifically. The instrument was upgraded with a Hawaii-2RG and ASIC readout system.  During engineering tests in March, 2016, the raw sensitivity was improved by a factor of 2, and when combined with the grating upgrade that was completed in the prior year, we see a total sensitivity increase at JH&K bands of factors of 3, 2.4, and 3.6, respectively.

The team designed a new detector mount for the detector head and incorporated a focus mechanism that was very valuable to the instrument. The focus mechanism design was based on mechanisms in the MOSFIRE and GPI instruments, but was modified to incorporate a cryogenic translation stage from Physik Instruments to provide greater range of focus adjustment than the range available from the heritage design. The focus stage upgrade included a new controller, cables, and of course new software to control the stage. Being able to adjust focus, enabled us to maximize the image quality on the detector, and we optimized the relative position of the lenslet to produce a sharper PSF shape on the detector for improved spectral extraction.

Following a successful hardware upgrade, the OSIRIS team focused their attention on updating the DRP that is required for real-time data display as well as post processing and analysis. While the new detector created a sensitivity gain and adjustments improved the PSF, the improved image quality revealed underlying issues in the data reduction that have existed in the software. The thought was that the hardware modifications would improve the point spread function sufficiently such that we could modify the pipeline and gain additional sensitivity with the reduction of data artifacts. The OSIRIS DRP team held four “hackathons” to probe the deficiencies of the existing DRP, test new code, and release new DRP versions to the community. The results of these hackthons and the code releases are well documented on the DRP code repository and issue tracking system that was developed for this project. More details on the DRP status is found in reports posted at: https://www2.keck.hawaii.edu/inst/osiris/tools/index.php.

Observers throughout the US community are able to take advantage of this upgrade either through the NASA allocated time or through collaborations with observers at Keck Observatory partner institutions which includes Caltech, the Universities of California, Yale, and Swinburne. Multiple graduate students and post docs participated in both the hardware and DRP software modifications and one thesis dissertation was completed by a minority in the field.
